metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix (No.7 eddy covariance system )
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.7 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 29 May to 18 September, 2012. The site (100.36521° E, 38.87676° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556.39 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.8 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Can eddy covariance systems be used to accurately validate evapotranspiration measurements in heterogeneous landscapes?

What challenges are associated with the availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting data on eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Example.Answer: One example of a challenge in collecting data on eco-hydrological processes is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders the progress in upscaling these processes on a heterogeneous surface.

Feature Specification.Question: What factors influence the choice of sensor types used in multiscale eco-hydrological observations?
Feature Specification.Answer: LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, L-band microwave radiometers, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data, synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the eddy covariance data collection method used in observing evapotranspiration?
Feature Specification.Answer: high frequency (10 Hz), outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, density correction, 30-minute intervals, quality assessment based on atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics

Quantification.Question: How many intensive observation periods (IOPs) were conducted during HiWATER to gather multiscale eco-hydrological data?
Quantification.Answer: The exact number is not specified.

Quantification.Question: What is the elevation at which the meteorological parameters were measured in the Daman superstation?

Definition.Question: What are the main challenges associated with measuring evapotranspiration using remote sensing in heterogeneous landscapes?
Definition.Answer: The main challenges associated with measuring evapotranspiration using remote sensing in heterogeneous landscapes include the complexity of separating soil and canopy component temperatures due to mixed pixel classifications and the strong advective conditions found in certain agricultural areas. Additionally, uncertainties in temperature measurements can arise from errors in image classification, atmospheric radiation influences, and the estimation of incoming solar radiation transmittance, which can affect the accuracy of models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model used to estimate evapotranspiration.

Comparison.Question: How does the challenge of incomplete energy balance closure in eddy covariance measurements compare with the challenges in thermal infrared temperature estimation in strongly advective regions?
Comparison.Answer: Incomplete energy balance closure in eddy covariance measurements is primarily due to uncertainties in available energy calculations, while thermal infrared temperature estimation challenges arise from errors in component temperature separation and atmospheric effects. Both challenges impact the accuracy of heat flux estimations in strongly advective areas.

Interpretation.Question: How can the application of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in heterogeneous landscapes aid in refining data collection methods for evapotranspiration measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The TSEB model allows for more accurate estimations of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by considering the separate soil and canopy components in heterogeneous landscapes. This model has undergone revisions to improve the estimation of net radiation, aerodynamic resistance, and component temperatures, which helps refine data collection methods by requiring only a single measurement of land surface temperature.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise when using multiscale observation techniques to study eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: The primary challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders the progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes. Addressing these challenges involves the use of hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, such as eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as a combination of airborne remote sensing missions and ground measurements, to capture data across different spatial scales.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can multiscale datasets contribute to the understanding and modeling of evapotranspiration in complex agricultural landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: Multiscale datasets provide comprehensive data that include flux observations, meteorological parameters, soil moisture, and vegetation dynamics, which are crucial for understanding and modeling evapotranspiration. These datasets facilitate the evaluation of models like the TSEB model and support the partitioning of evapotranspiration into its individual components, helping to improve model accuracy and applicability in complex agricultural landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the collection of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes considered difficult?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The collection of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes is difficult due to the poor availability of multiscale data, challenges in instrumenting hierarchically nested scales, and the need for comprehensive data that cover diverse landscapes and interactions within oasis-desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes of errors in component temperature estimations using thermal infrared cameras?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in component temperature estimations using thermal infrared cameras are primarily caused by image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, the exclusion of atmospheric radiation effects, and the uncertainties in short- and long-wave radiation transmittances, which may lead to inaccuracies in estimating soil and canopy temperatures.

Causal Consequence.Question: When employing eddy covariance systems for flux measurements, what are the potential consequences of incomplete energy balance closure on the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates?
Causal Consequence.Answer: In a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area, incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0 can lead to challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes like H and LE. This can affect the performance of models such as the TSEB model, which relies on accurate surface-air temperature differences.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing a multiscale observation system on studying eco-hydrological processes over heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: A multiscale observation system, such as the one used in HiWATER, can capture complex eco-hydrological processes by providing diverse datasets from various scales and instruments. This approach can enhance understanding and modeling of interactions between different land cover types, such as oasis-desert interactions, and improve data quality through hierarchical nesting, addressing the challenges posed by heterogeneous landscapes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of implementing multiscale observations in the collection of eco-hydrological data over heterogeneous surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals of implementing multiscale observations are to address the challenge of poor availability of such data in eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, as well as to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes using hierarchically nested scales. This is achieved through instrumentation and intensive observation periods, such as those conducted during the HiWATER experiment.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate evapotranspiration estimation models using ground-based measurements in strongly advective environments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to validate evapotranspiration estimation models using ground-based measurements in strongly advective environments to ensure the accuracy of the model's estimates of evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET). Given the complexity and uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences in such environments, ground-based measurements provide reliable data for model validation, as demonstrated by the use of the TSEB model with soil and canopy component temperatures.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to ensure the quality control of datasets collected during multiscale eco-hydrological observations in heterogeneous surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: All observational data from the HiWATER project were carefully quality controlled through sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are eddy covariance measurements processed to correct for potential errors in flux data collected from non-uniform underlying surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The flux data from eddy covariance measurements are processed using several correction steps: despiking of outlier values, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Quality evaluation of flux values includes tests for atmospheric stationarity and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation and procedural strategies are utilized to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert interaction study?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The HiWATER project employed a hierarchical nested scale approach with instruments such as flux observation matrices of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Intensive observation periods included the use of a sparse network of EC towers and automatic meteorological stations across different landscapes, as well as airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enabled the accurate separation of evapotranspiration components in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-precision thermal infrared cameras to obtain soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, as well as the application of the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model, enabled the accurate separation of evapotranspiration components in heterogeneous landscapes.

Enablement.Question: How do the data collection methods using eddy covariance systems and remote sensing contribute to understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers provide multiscale and multidisciplinary data that help capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, enabling a deeper understanding of interactions in oasis-desert areas.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for implementing a multiscale observation experiment in a complex landscape like the Heihe River Basin?
Enablement.Answer: Implementing a multiscale observation experiment in a complex landscape like the Heihe River Basin requires a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup, including eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing platforms, along with intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations to capture multi-scale processes.

Expectation.Question: Why do composite temperature separation approaches face limitations in arid regions for data collection and analysis?
Expectation.Answer: Composite temperature separation approaches are limited in arid regions primarily due to image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. These errors can cause soil pixels to be misclassified as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimated canopy temperatures. Furthermore, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance contributes to uncertainties in temperature estimates, complicating the separation of soil and canopy temperatures.

Expectation.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations crucial for understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, and why might they be difficult to obtain?
Expectation.Answer: Upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces is challenging due to the poor availability of multiscale observations. These observations are crucial for capturing the complexity of interactions within ecosystems, such as oasis-desert interactions. The difficulty in obtaining such data lies in the need for extensive instrumentation across hierarchically nested scales, which involves complex setups like eddy covariance towers, remote sensing, and ground-based measurements to capture the multiscale and multidisciplinary data necessary for comprehensive analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What is your judgment on the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems as a data collection method for measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The eddy covariance system is effective for measuring evapotranspiration, especially when combined with ground-based measurements to partition ET into its components. However, challenges such as incomplete energy balance closure and uncertainties due to strong advective environments can affect its accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the challenges in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes, especially in terms of data availability and quality control?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in obtaining multiscale observations are significant due to the poor availability of data and the need for rigorous quality control. The HiWATER experiment addresses these challenges through hierarchically nested scales and a comprehensive quality control process, but the complexity of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces remains a hurdle.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the potential for using high-resolution thermal infrared cameras in enhancing the accuracy of evapotranspiration models?
Judgmental.Answer: High-resolution thermal infrared cameras have significant potential to enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration models by providing robust soil and vegetation component temperature data. This can improve the separation of E and T from ET, particularly in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, as demonstrated by their reliable performance in combination with the TSEB model.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from heterogeneous land surfaces can be accurately collected and processed for evapotranspiration estimation.
Assertion.Answer: The collection and processing of data from heterogeneous land surfaces for evapotranspiration estimation involve using multiscale observation techniques, as seen in the HiWATER experiment. This includes the use of eddy covariance systems, thermal infrared cameras, and the partitioning of data into soil and canopy components for more accurate modeling. Challenges such as image classification errors and incomplete energy balance closure are addressed through ground measurements and model adjustments.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas include the poor availability of multiscale observations and the complexity of capturing interactions across different landscapes. The HiWATER experiment addresses this by using hierarchically nested scales and a sparse network of instruments such as EC towers and automatic meteorological stations. These setups help capture the diverse eco-hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of potential datasets that can be used for studying eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems, and discuss their data quality control measures.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems include those from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER), which comprises flux observation matrices, remote sensing data, and synchronical ground measurements. The data quality is ensured through sensor calibration, careful data collection, processing, and generation. These datasets are available at platforms such as figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the experimental setup and instruments used in the HiWATER project to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, noting any innovative techniques applied.
Request/Directive.Answer: The HiWATER project utilized a hierarchically nested setup with a sparse network of instruments, including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations across various landscapes. Innovative techniques included the use of hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing with LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes.
